title: How can a person be right and wrong at the same time? - Quora

response.answer_text: John and Peter were stranded on an Island with no vegetation. It would take 2 weeks for the aid to come but somehow they’ve managed to collect some food from their wrecked ship. However, the food will only last them for a week unless one of them is dead. Peter realized it first and proceeds on killing John.  Doing everything for survival is naturally right. Killing is morally wrong. Peter is right and wrong at the same time at different viewpoints.

I sadly cannot find the source. This was a TV ad (remember those?) for a UK Newspaper (one of the more sensible ones, if I recall correctly. If someone finds it on YooToob (sic), please drop me the link! Anyhow: It’s three camera angles of the same scene. Scene one: You see a guy running around the corner of a building and sprinting out of the image along the sidewalk. Scene two: Same situation, but you see how a car pulled up behind the guy, pointed at him and then the guy sprints away. So it looks like he’s running away from the guys in the car. Scene three: Wide angle. You see what’s happening. The guys in the car are not pointing at the sprinter, but past him, at a crane palette of bricks about to crash to the pavement, with a pedestrian underneath. The guys in the car point that out, shouting a warning. The guy sprints away and manages to save the pedestrian by tackling him to the ground. Three perspective. Three stories. Which one is “right”? All of them.

Don’t do any thing which heart doesn’t agree to do. Follow your heart & keep mind open. You are always Right. Don’t bother if others feel it wrong.

If a person acts according to his or her conscience, even though it may be considered wrong at a particular time and a particular place, he or she is right.So I would say such a person can definitely be right and what’s wrong in the eyes of the people around him. However there can be no time when a person can be right and wrong according to his or her conscience or inner voice.

In traffic, pedestrians always have the “right of way.” Some pedestrians take this to the extreme and step out in front of moving traffic, expecting the cars to stop. Sometimes the pedestrian gets run over, even though they had the “right of way.” So, you can be “right,” but you might end up dead right - and that’s just wrong.

It's called different perspectives. You can firmly believe your dance moves are correct while those around you think you only invent your own moves. And you really know correct consistency of spaghetti carbonara while an american chef says you are wrong.
